topic.name: Historical Books
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Historical Books in Bible & Theology

objectives.objective_text: Identify this book as a history of God's kings.
Name David and Solomon as the main heroes.
Identify Solomon as the wise king who built the Temple.
Name Elijah as the prophet who went up to heaven.
Identify Samuel as the boy who heard God call him.
Name David and Goliath.
Identify Esther as a Jewish queen.
Name Mordecai as her wise cousin.
Identify Ezra as a teacher of God's Word.
Name the Temple as what they built again.
Identify Joshua as the leader who fought the Battle of Jericho.
Name Rahab as the woman who helped the spies.
Identify Samson and Gideon.
Name the Judges as leaders before there were kings.
Identify Nehemiah as the cupbearer to the king.
Name the Wall of Jerusalem as what they built.
Identify Ruth as a loyal daughter-in-law.
Name Boaz as the kind man.
Recall that they loved the Temple.
Observe that lists of names show God remembers everyone.
Recall that the kingdom broke into two pieces.
Observe that bad kings made the people worship idols.
Recall that Saul was the first king, but David was the best king.
Observe that David loved God with all his heart.
Recall that she was brave to talk to the king.
Observe that God saved His people from bad Haman.
Recall that the people came back home from Babylon.
Observe that they were happy to read the Bible again.
Recall that the walls fell down when they shouted.
Observe that God keeps His promises to give them the land.
Recall that the people forgot God many times.
Observe that God saved them when they prayed.
Recall that they worked with a tool in one hand and a sword in the other.
Observe that Nehemiah prayed before he acted.
Recall that Ruth picked up grain in the fields.
Observe that King David came from Ruth's family.
Summarize the focus on the Temple and worship.
Explain that Chronicles retells the story of Samuel/Kings.
Explain the theme of 'seeking the Lord'.
Perform research on the post-exilic context.
Summarize the story of Elijah on Mount Carmel.
Explain why the kingdom divided (Rehoboam).
Categorize kings as 'Good' (like Hezekiah) or 'Bad' (like Ahab).
Explain the sin of Jeroboam (golden calves).
Defend the justice of the Exile based on covenant curses.
Produce a study on the contest between Yahweh and Baal.
Summarize the transition from Judges to Kings.
Explain why God chose David (looks at the heart).
Explain the political unification of the tribes under David.
Perform research on the historiography of the 'Court History of David'.
Summarize how Esther became queen.
Explain the plot to destroy the Jews.
Explain the vulnerability of Jews in the diaspora.
Defend the doctrine of Providence using Esther as a case study.
Produce an essay on anti-semitism in the ancient world.
Summarize the decree of Cyrus allowing the return.
Explain the opposition to building the Temple.
Explain the role of the scribe.
Defend the continuity of the covenant despite the lack of a king.
Summarize the crossing of the Jordan and the fall of Jericho.
Explain the sin of Achan.
Explain the concept of Herem (Holy War/Devoted to Destruction).
Perform research on the Amarna Letters and the Habiru.
Summarize the cycle of Judges: Sin, Oppression, Repentance, Deliverance.
Explain how Gideon defeated the Midianites.
Categorize the enemies (Philistines, Moabites, etc.).
Explain the role of the Holy Spirit coming upon the Judges.
Defend the sovereignty of God in using flawed human instruments.
Produce an essay on the spiral of apostasy.
Summarize how Nehemiah organized the people to build.
Explain why walls were important for a city.
Explain the significance of the city of Jerusalem.
Perform research on the topography of Jerusalem's walls.
Summarize the story of Naomi's return to Bethlehem.
Explain what a 'Kinsman Redeemer' is.
Explain the levirate marriage custom.
Defend the inclusion of Gentiles in the plan of salvation.
Compare the spies in Joshua 2 with the spies in Numbers 13.
Compare how Chronicles leaves out David's bad sin (Bathsheba).
Apply the prayer of Jabez or Jehoshaphat.
Analyze why Chronicles was written (for the returning exiles).
Interpret the focus on the Southern Kingdom (Judah) over the North.
Connect the genealogy to the identity of the post-exilic community.
Compare the Northern Kingdom (Israel) and Southern Kingdom (Judah).
Analyze the ministry of Elijah and Elisha (miracles and confrontation).
Interpret the fall of Samaria (722 BC) and Jerusalem (586 BC).
Connect the reforms of Josiah to the Book of the Law.
Compare Saul's disobedience with David's repentance.
Apply the lesson of friendship between David and Jonathan.
Analyze the Davidic Covenant in 2 Samuel 7.
Interpret the fall of the Ark of the Covenant.
Connect David's sin with Bathsheba to the turmoil in his family.
Compare the pride of Haman with the honor of Mordecai.
Apply the phrase 'For such a time as this'.
Analyze the fact that God's name is not mentioned in the book.
Interpret the feast of Purim.
Connect the story to the providence of God.
Compare the first return (Zerubbabel) and second return (Ezra).
Apply Ezra's example of studying and doing God's law.
Analyze the spiritual condition of the returnees.
Interpret the problem of intermarriage in Ezra.
Connect the rebuilding of the altar to true worship.
Apply the verse 'Be strong and courageous'.
Analyze the three military campaigns (Central, Southern, Northern).
Interpret the sun standing still (Joshua 10).
Connect the land allotment to the tribal promises.
Compare the strength of Samson with his weakness for sin.
Analyze the refrain 'In those days there was no king in Israel'.
Interpret the tragic vow of Jephthah.
Connect the moral decline to the religious compromise.
Compare Nehemiah (governor) with Ezra (priest).
Apply Nehemiah's leadership skills.
Analyze the social justice issues Nehemiah addressed (usury).
Interpret the opposition of Sanballat and Tobiah.
Connect the reading of the Law to the renewal of the covenant.
Compare the choice of Orpah (left) and Ruth (stayed).
Apply the loyalty of Ruth to our friendships.
Analyze the literary structure of the book.
Interpret the significance of a Moabite in the line of Christ.
Connect the timeline of Ruth to the period of the Judges.
Evaluate the theological purpose of idealizing David and Solomon.
Evaluate the role of the prophet vis--vis the king.
Evaluate the character of Absalom and his rebellion.
Evaluate the moral complexity of Esther's marriage to a pagan king.
Evaluate the exclusivity of the post-exilic community.
Evaluate the archaeological record of the destruction of Hazor.
Evaluate the disturbing ending of the book (civil war).
Evaluate the effectiveness of the reforms (did they last?).
Evaluate the role of providence in the book (God is never named as acting directly).
Construct a comparison of Kings (prophetic history) vs. Chronicles (priestly history).
Synthesize the hope for the Son of David found in Chronicles.
Construct a synchronized timeline of the divided monarchy.
Construct a contrast between theocratic rule and monarchical rule.
Synthesize the messianic themes in the Song of Hannah and David's Last Words.
Construct an argument for the book's canonicity.
Construct a timeline of the Persian kings in Ezra.
Synthesize the relationship between Ezra and Nehemiah.
Construct a defense of the morality of the Canaanite conquest.
Synthesize the theme of 'Rest' in Joshua and the NT.
Construct a chart of the Judges and their geographical areas.
Construct a profile of biblical leadership based on Nehemiah.
Synthesize the theme of prayer and action in the book.
Construct a character study of Boaz as a type of Christ.
Synthesize the book as a bridge between Judges and the Monarchy.
